TEXT:
TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   - encephalopathic all night
   - complaints of thirst all night
   - Had BMx4, soft not diarrhea; checking C diff on next one
   - lasix boluses x2, after which net neg -500cc, started lasix drip ~5am
   ; urinary output didn't change which 20mg IV bolus (already had
   100cc/hr output), increased w 40mg IV bolus
   - dopamine turned off 3am, but restarted for MAPs in mid 50s
   - patient pulled out Swan and central line this AM
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:
   Infusions:

   Furosemide (Lasix) - 5 mg/hour

   Physical Examination
   GENERAL: elderly male, sleepy but easily arousable and conversational,
   in NAD
   HEENT: NCAT. Sclera anicteric. PERRL, EOMI. Conjunctiva with multiple
   petechiae
   NECK: Supple with JVP of 10 cm.
   CARDIAC: PMI located in 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line. RR,
   normal S1, S2. III/VI systolic murmur loudest at right 2nd intercostal
   space with loud radiation to carotids No S3 or S4.
   LUNGS: No chest wall deformities, scoliosis or kyphosis. Respirations
   unlabored, no accessory muscle use. bibasilar crackles more clear in
   mid and upper lung fields
   ABDOMEN: Soft, NTND. Spleen not palpable, no hepatomegaly No abdominial
   bruits.
   EXTREMITIES: No c/c/e. No femoral bruits.
   SKIN: Multiple areas of bruising, multiple petechiae over palms and
   soles ; painless dark spots in toes and fingers
   PULSES:
   Right: Carotid 2+ DP 2+ PT 2+
   Left: Carotid 2+ DP 2+ PT 2+
   Neuro: The patient has poor attention span; cannot always finish train
   of thought when speaking in sentences
   Labs / Radiology
   41 K/uL

   Glucose
   156
   127
   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:16.3/33.5/1.4, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:277/6/0.20, ALT / AST:59/92, Alk Phos / T Bili:39/1.7,
   Differential-Neuts:84.6 %, Lymph:9.9 %, Mono:5.2 %, Eos:0.1 %,
   Fibrinogen:351 mg/dL, Lactic Acid:1.8 mmol/L, Albumin:2.4 g/dL, LDH:415
   IU/L, Ca++:7.4 mg/dL, Mg++:2.7 mg/dL, PO4:4.1 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   75y/o M with a PMH of CAD s/p CABG with AVR in [**2164**] and
   thrombocytopenia transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] for management of S. aureus
   bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic CHF
   # Bacteremia - The patient was found to have 4/4 bottles growing
   Staphylococcus aureus. Concern for endovascular source of infection
   given high grade bacteremia. No clear portal of entry as the patient
   denies recent procedures/dental work, no focal symptoms. Given his
   presentation with community acquired bacteremia with symptoms of [**12-23**]
   day duration prior to presentation pt is at high risk for complicated
   bacteremia, including endocarditis. MSSA bacteremia speciation per new
   outside hospital records this morning.
   - Will switch to Nafcillin for better coverage of MSSA
   - TTE this AM
   - TEE today given bioprosthetic aortic valve
   - If evidence of vegetation or new/worsening valvular dysfunction,
   consider addition of gentamicin/rifamplin for S. aureus prosthetic
   valve endocarditis
   - Will obtain surveillance blood cultures
   - Appreciate ID recs
   .
   # Hypotension - Presentation of hypotension in setting of bacteremia
   could be consistent with sepsis, however the patient has a mixed
   picture given PCWP of 32 and CVP 14-24. Also consider worsening aortic
   valvular function in the setting of endocarditis. Currently, the
   patient appears volume overloaded with elevated JVP. Per reports
   pressor requirements have decreased since beginning diuresis.  Neo
   weaned off.  Dopamine weaned off overnight but restarted.  Patient
   pulled out PA catheter this AM.
   - Continue to taper dopamine
   - Continue lasix gtt
   - Treat bacteremia as above
   - TEE as above to evaluate EF/valvular dysfunction
   .
   # Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF - Pt currently with evidence of volume
   overload as above
   - continue lasix gtt
   - Plan for beta blocker and ACE-I once BP allows
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia - Per OSH reports the patient has a chronic
   thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology. Pt reports history of easy
   bleeding & bruising. DDx is broad and includes ITP, myelodysplastic
   syndrome, drug induced - ex. hydroxychloroquin, unclear when this was
   started, infection with HIV or HCV, nutritional deficiency
   (B12/Folate), EtOH toxicity however no clear history of this. DIC less
   concerning given long history of thrombocytopenia and fibrinogen
   normal. HIT also unlikely given documented long history of
   thrombocytopenia.  LFTs and LDH elevated.
   - check HIV
   - F/U B12/folate
   - Trend INR
   - Check peripheral smear
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation/Atrial Flutter - the pt reports a history of AF
   however no documented history of this, pt not on anticoagulation.
   Currently ECG shows A. flutter in the setting of pressors.  Currently
   Rate controlled.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Elevated CK/Troponin - No prior ECG for comparison, no clear
   ischemia. Trop bump most likely occurred in the setting of hypotension
   secondary to infection.  Likely demand in setting of hypotension. Not
   concerned for ACS.
   - Continue statin
   - Start BB and ACE-I as BP allows
   .
   # Encephalopathy - Most likely toxic/metabolic in the setting of
   infection. Per report OSH Head CT negative for acute process. Pt also
   had been treated with sedatives at OSH ativan/precedex .  Continues to
   be encephalopathic, though appears mildly improved.
   - Hold sedating medications
   - Treat infection
   - Consider repeat Head CT ; will likely need MRI in future when can
   tolerate to eval for septic emboli
   # Rheumatoid Arthritis
   - holding meds ; does not  likely need further stress dose steroids
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PA Catheter - [**2168-1-6**] 07:15 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2168-1-7**] 05:28 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer:  none
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:  Full
   Disposition: CCU

   Cardiology Teaching Physician Note
   On this day I saw, examined and was physically present with the
   resident / fellow for the key portions of the services provided. I
   agree with the above note and plans.
   I would add the following remarks:
   History
   nothing to add

   nothing to add
   Total time spent on patient care: 45 minutes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old male with a past medical history of coronary artery disease, status post coronary artery bypass grafting with aortic valve replacement, and thrombocytopenia. He was admitted to the ICU for management of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic congestive heart failure.

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Encephalopathic state, with complaints of thirst and difficulty concentrating
2. Thrombocytopenia with a platelet count of 41 K/uL
3. Hypotension, with a blood pressure of 115/55 mmHg
4. Elevated cardiac enzymes, including troponin-T of 0.20 ng/mL
5. Atrial fibrillation/flutter, with a heart rate of 75 bpm
6. Fluid overload, with a central venous pressure of 15-24 mmHg
7. Respiratory support, with oxygen delivery via nasal cannula
8. Abnormal laboratory results, including elevated lactate dehydrogenase (415 IU/L), alkaline phosphatase (39 U/L), and troponin-T

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Endocarditis, given the patient's history of bacteremia and the presence of a bioprosthetic aortic valve
2. Sepsis, given the patient's hypotension and elevated cardiac enzymes
3. Respiratory failure, given the patient's fluid overload and abnormal lung sounds
4. Thrombotic complications, given the patient's thrombocytopenia and history of easy bleeding and bruising
5. Encephalopathy, given the patient's altered mental status and elevated liver enzymes
6. Cardiac failure, given the patient's history of acute on chronic systolic congestive heart failure and elevated cardiac enzymes
7. Infection, given the patient's bacteremia and abnormal laboratory results

The plan of care includes:

1. Treatment of bacteremia with nafcillin
2. TTE and TEE to evaluate endocarditis and valvular dysfunction
3. Continue lasix drip to manage fluid overload
4. Taper dopamine and wean off pressors
5. Consider repeat Head CT and MRI to evaluate for septic emboli
6. Monitor for signs of sepsis, respiratory failure, and cardiac failure
7. Continue to manage the patient's thrombocytopenia and bleeding risk
8. Consider anticoagulation therapy to prevent thrombotic complications
9. Monitor for signs of encephalopathy and consider repeat Head CT and MRI
10. Plan for beta blocker and ACE-I therapy once blood pressure allows.

   75y/o M with a PMH of CAD s/p CABG with AVR in [**2164**] and
   thrombocytopenia transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] for management of S. aureus
   bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic CHF
   # Bacteremia - The patient was found to have 4/4 bottles growing
   Staphylococcus aureus. Concern for endovascular source of infection
   given high grade bacteremia. No clear portal of entry as the patient
   denies recent procedures/dental work, no focal symptoms. Given his
   presentation with community acquired bacteremia with symptoms of [**12-23**]
   day duration prior to presentation pt is at high risk for complicated
   bacteremia, including endocarditis. MSSA bacteremia speciation per new
   outside hospital records this morning.
   - Will switch to Nafcillin for better coverage of MSSA
   - TTE this AM
   - TEE today given bioprosthetic aortic valve
   - If evidence of vegetation or new/worsening valvular dysfunction,
   consider addition of gentamicin/rifamplin for S. aureus prosthetic
   valve endocarditis
   - Will obtain surveillance blood cultures
   - Appreciate ID recs
   .
   # Hypotension - Presentation of hypotension in setting of bacteremia
   could be consistent with sepsis, however the patient has a mixed
   picture given PCWP of 32 and CVP 14-24. Also consider worsening aortic
   valvular function in the setting of endocarditis. Currently, the
   patient appears volume overloaded with elevated JVP. Per reports
   pressor requirements have decreased since beginning diuresis.  Neo
   weaned off.  Dopamine weaned off overnight but restarted.  Patient
   pulled out PA catheter this AM.
   - Continue to taper dopamine
   - Continue lasix gtt
   - Treat bacteremia as above
   - TEE as above to evaluate EF/valvular dysfunction
   .
   # Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF - Pt currently with evidence of volume
   overload as above
   - continue lasix gtt
   - Plan for beta blocker and ACE-I once BP allows
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia - Per OSH reports the patient has a chronic
   thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology. Pt reports history of easy
   bleeding & bruising. DDx is broad and includes ITP, myelodysplastic
   syndrome, drug induced - ex. hydroxychloroquin, unclear when this was
   started, infection with HIV or HCV, nutritional deficiency
   (B12/Folate), EtOH toxicity however no clear history of this. DIC less
   concerning given long history of thrombocytopenia and fibrinogen
   normal. HIT also unlikely given documented long history of
   thrombocytopenia.  LFTs and LDH elevated.
   - check HIV
   - F/U B12/folate
   - Trend INR
   - Check peripheral smear
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation/Atrial Flutter - the pt reports a history of AF
   however no documented history of this, pt not on anticoagulation.
   Currently ECG shows A. flutter in the setting of pressors.  Currently
   Rate controlled.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Elevated CK/Troponin - No prior ECG for comparison, no clear
   ischemia. Trop bump most likely occurred in the setting of hypotension
   secondary to infection.  Likely demand in setting of hypotension. Not
   concerned for ACS.
   - Continue statin
   - Start BB and ACE-I as BP allows
   .
   # Encephalopathy - Most likely toxic/metabolic in the setting of
   infection. Per report OSH Head CT negative for acute process. Pt also
   had been treated with sedatives at OSH ativan/precedex .  Continues to
   be encephalopathic, though appears mildly improved.
   - Hold sedating medications
   - Treat infection
   - Consider repeat Head CT ; will likely need MRI in future when can
   tolerate to eval for septic emboli
   # Rheumatoid Arthritis
   - holding meds ; does not  likely need further stress dose steroids
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PA Catheter - [**2168-1-6**] 07:15 PM
   20 Gauge - [**2168-1-7**] 05:28 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT:  pneumoboots
   Stress ulcer:  none
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status:  Full
   Disposition: CCU

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with a past medical history of coronary artery disease (CAD), post-myocardial infarction (MI) with aortic valve replacement (AVR), and thrombocytopenia. He was transferred to the ICU for management of Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF). The patient has been treated with antibiotics, diuretics, and pressors, and has been found to have a mixed picture of sepsis and volume overload. He has also been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation/atrial flutter, elevated creatine kinase (CK) and troponin, and encephalopathy.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Endovascular source of infection: Given the high-grade bacteremia, there is a concern for an endovascular source of infection, which may require further evaluation and treatment.
2. Endocarditis: The patient's history of bacteremia and the presence of a bioprosthetic aortic valve increase the risk of endocarditis, which may require additional treatment with gentamicin and rifampin.
3. Sepsis: The patient's presentation with hypotension, tachycardia, and elevated lactate levels suggests sepsis, which may require further treatment with antibiotics and supportive care.
4. Volume overload: The patient's elevated central venous pressure (CVP) and jugular venous distension (JVD) suggest volume overload, which may require further treatment with diuretics and vasopressors.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's history of thrombocytopenia may increase the risk of bleeding, particularly in the setting of antibiotic therapy and sepsis.
6. Atrial fibrillation/atrial flutter: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation/atrial flutter may increase the risk of stroke and embolism, particularly in the setting of sepsis and endocarditis.
7. Encephalopathy: The patient's encephalopathy may be related to sepsis, metabolic abnormalities, or sedative medications, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
8. Sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy: The patient's elevated troponin levels and reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) suggest sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy, which may require further treatment with vasopressors and inotropes.

   Assessment and Plan
   # Bacteremia - The patient was found to have 4/4 bottles growing
   Staphylococcus aureus. Concern for endovascular source of infection
   given high grade bacteremia. No clear portal of entry as the patient
   denies recent procedures/dental work, no focal symptoms. Given his
   presentation with community acquired bacteremia with symptoms of [**12-23**]
   day duration prior to presentation pt is at high risk for complicated
   bacteremia, including endocarditis. By Duke Criteria - he has major
   criteria of high gradebacteremia with typical organism, by minor
   criteria he has fever, predisposing heart condition, he also has skin
   findings of petechiae however difficult to interpret in the setting of
   significant thrombocytopenia.
   - Will continue Vancoymcin dosed 1 gm Q 12
   - Contact[**Name (NI) **] OSH micro lab - SA is likely MSSA but sensitivities are not
   finalized, will fax results in am - if so, plan to transition to
   nafcillin
   - TEE given bioprosthetic aortic valve
   - If evidence of vegetation or new/worsening valvular dysfunction,
   consider addition of gentamicin/rifamplin for S. aureus prosthetic
   valve endocarditis
   - Will obtain surveillance blood cultures
   - ID consult in am given high grade Staph aureus bacteremia
   .
   # Hypotension - Presentation of hypotension in setting of bacteremia
   could be consistent with sepsis, however the patient has a mixed
   picture given PCWP of 32 and CVP 14-24. Also consider worsening aortic
   valvular function in the setting of endocarditis. Currently, the
   patient appears volume overloaded with elevated JVP. Per reports
   pressor requirements have decreased since beginning diuresis.  Neo
   weaned off.  Dopamine weaned off overnight but restarted.  Patient
   pulled out PA catheter this AM.
   - Continue to taper dopamine
   - Continue lasix gtt
   - Treat bacteremia as above
   - TEE as above to evaluate EF/valvular dysfunction
   .
   # Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF - Pt currently with evidence of volume
   overload as above
   - continue lasix gtt
   - Plan for beta blocker and ACE-I once BP allows
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia - Per OSH reports the patient has a chronic
   thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology. Pt reports history of easy
   bleeding & bruising. DDx is broad and includes ITP, myelodysplastic
   syndrome, drug induced - ex. hydroxychloroquin, unclear when this was
   started, infection with HIV or HCV, nutritional deficiency
   (B12/Folate), EtOH toxicity however no clear history of this. DIC less
   concerning given long history of thrombocytopenia and fibrinogen
   normal. HIT also unlikely given documented long history of
   thrombocytopenia.  LFTs and LDH elevated.
   - F/U B12/folate
   - Trend INR
   - Check peripheral smear
   - Consider hematology consult in am
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation/Atrial Flutter - the pt reports a history of AF
   however no documented history of this, pt not on anticoagulation.
   Currently ECG shows A. flutter however this is in the setting of
   pressors
   - Monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Elevated CK/Troponin - No prior ECG for comparison, no clear
   ischemia. Trop bump most likely occurred in the setting of hypotension
   secondary to infection
   - Continue statin
   - Start BB and ACE-I as BP allows
   .
   # Encephalopathy - Most likely toxic/metabolic in the setting of
   infection. Per report OSH Head CT negative for acute process. Pt also
   had been treated with sedatives at OSH ativan/precedex
   - Hold sedating medications
   - Treat infection
   - Consider repeat Head CT
   # Rheumatoid Arthritis
   - holding meds

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 69-inch tall male who has been admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of encephalopathic symptoms and complaints of thirst all night. The patient has a history of chronic thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology and has been diagnosed with Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Tmax: 37.7C (99.8F)
* Tcurrent: 37.4C (99.3F)
* HR: 75 (68-85) bpm
* BP: 115/55 (71) mmHg
* RR: 19 (12-25) inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 97%
* Heart rhythm: Atrial Flutter

The patient's lab results show:

* WBC: 7.7
* Hct: 34.6
* Plt: 43
* Cr: 2.0
* TropT: 0.20
* TCO2: 21
* Glucose: 156
* Other lab results: PT/PTT/INR: 16.3/33.5/1.4, CK/CKMB/Troponin-T: 277/6/0.20, ALT/AST: 59/92, Alk Phos/T Bili: 39/1.7, Differential-Neuts: 84.6%, Lymph: 9.9%, Mono: 5.2%, Eos: 0.1%, Fibrinogen: 351 mg/dL, Lactic Acid: 1.8 mmol/L, Albumin: 2.4 g/dL, LDH: 415 IU/L, Ca++: 7.4 mg/dL, Mg++: 2.7 mg/dL, PO4: 4.1 mg/dL

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue Vancomycin dosed 1 gram every 12 hours
* Contact OSH micro lab for sensitivities of Staphylococcus aureus
* Consider addition of gentamicin/rifampin for S. aureus prosthetic valve endocarditis
* Obtain surveillance blood cultures
* ID consult in the morning
* Continue to taper dopamine
* Continue lasix drip
* Treat bacteremia as above
* TEE to evaluate EF/valvular dysfunction
* Continue to monitor for signs of endocarditis

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Endocarditis: Given the patient's diagnosis of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia and the presence of a bioprosthetic aortic valve, there is a high risk of developing endocarditis.
* Sepsis: The patient's presentation with bacteremia and signs of volume overload increases the risk of developing sepsis.
* Thrombocytopenia: The patient's chronic thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology increases the risk of bleeding complications.
* Atrial fibrillation/atrial flutter: The patient's history of atrial fibrillation and current presentation with atrial flutter increases the risk of developing cardiac arrhythmias.
* Encephalopathy: The patient's current presentation with encephalopathic symptoms increases the risk of developing further neurological complications.
* Acute kidney injury: The patient's current presentation with elevated creatinine levels increases the risk of developing acute kidney injury.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust the plan of care accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and aortic valve replacement (AVR) who was transferred to the ICU for management of Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic heart failure.

The patient's condition is complicated by:

1. Endocarditis: The patient has a high-grade bacteremia, and the ID recs suggest that he is at high risk for complicated bacteremia, including endocarditis. A TEE was performed, which showed a thickened aortic valve bioprosthesis with high-than-normal transvalvular gradients, but no significant regurgitation.
2. Hypotension: The patient's presentation of hypotension in the setting of bacteremia could be consistent with sepsis, but the patient also has a mixed picture given the elevated PCWP and CVP. The patient is currently volume overloaded, and the PA catheter was self-DCed by the patient this morning.
3. Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF: The patient has evidence of volume overload, and the plan is to continue lasix gtt and treat the bacteremia as above.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a chronic thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology, and the differential diagnosis is broad. The patient's LFTs and LDH are elevated, and the peripheral smear showed no schistocytes.
5. Atrial Fibrillation/Atrial Flutter: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, but no documented history of atrial flutter. The patient is currently rate-controlled.
6. Elevated CK/Troponin: The patient's elevated CK and troponin are likely due to hypotension secondary to infection, rather than acute coronary syndrome.
7. Encephalopathy: The patient is encephalopathic, likely due to toxic or metabolic causes in the setting of infection. The patient's Head CT was negative for acute process, and the plan is to hold sedating medications, treat the infection, and repeat the Head CT in the future.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Endocarditis-related complications, such as valvular dysfunction, emboli, or abscesses.
2. Sepsis or septic shock due to the bacteremia.
3. Cardiac complications, such as CHF, arrhythmias, or cardiac tamponade.
4. Neurological complications, such as cerebral edema, seizures, or stroke.
5. Gastrointestinal complications, such as bleeding or perforation.
6. Renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
7. Hematological complications, such as disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) or hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Treatment of the bacteremia with nafcillin, and consideration of adding gentamicin and rifampin if the TEE is positive.
2. Tapering of dopamine and lasix gtt.
3. Monitoring of the patient's cardiac status, including echocardiograms and hemodynamic monitoring.
4. Management of the patient's thrombocytopenia, including checking HIV, F/U B12/folate, and trending INR.
5. Monitoring of the patient's neurological status, including repeat Head CT and potential MRI in the future.
6. Management of the patient's atrial fibrillation/flutter, including monitoring on telemetry.
7. Management of the patient's elevated CK and troponin, including continuing statin and starting beta blocker and ACE-I as BP allows.

   however no documented history of this, pt not on anticoagulation.
   Currently ECG shows A. flutter in the setting of pressors.  Currently

   ischemia. Trop bump most likely occurred in the setting of hypotension
   secondary to infection.  Likely demand in setting of hypotension. Not
   concerned for ACS.
   - Continue statin
   - Start BB and ACE-I as BP allows

   infection. Per report OSH Head CT negative for acute process. Pt also

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, post-coronary artery bypass grafting, and aortic valve replacement. He was transferred to the ICU for management of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic heart failure.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Endocarditis: The patient has a bioprosthetic aortic valve, and the echocardiogram showed thickened aortic valve bioprosthesis with high-than-normal transvalvular gradients, but no significant regurgitation.
2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is labile, and he has a mixed picture of sepsis and volume overload.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a chronic thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology, and the differential diagnosis includes idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, myelodysplastic syndrome, drug-induced thrombocytopenia, infection with HIV or HCV, nutritional deficiency, and ethanol toxicity.
4. Encephalopathy: The patient is encephalopathic, likely due to toxic or metabolic causes in the setting of infection.
5. Elevated CK/Troponin: The patient's troponin levels are elevated, likely due to hypotension and demand in the setting of infection.
6. Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF: The patient has evidence of volume overload, and his plan includes diuresis and consideration of beta blockers and ACE inhibitors once his blood pressure allows.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and hypotension make him at risk for sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and failure.
2. Endocarditis-related complications: The patient's bioprosthetic aortic valve makes him at risk for endocarditis-related complications, such as valve dysfunction, abscess formation, and embolization.
3. Thrombotic complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia and history of chronic thrombocytopenia make him at risk for thrombotic complications, such as deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.
4. Encephalopathy-related complications: The patient's encephalopathy can lead to complications such as seizures, brain edema, and prolonged hospitalization.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's acute on chronic systolic CHF and endocarditis make him at risk for cardiac complications, such as heart failure, cardiogenic shock, and arrhythmias.

The patient's treatment plan includes antibiotics, diuresis, and consideration of beta blockers and ACE inhibitors. He will also undergo further evaluation with echocardiography and imaging studies to assess his valve function and potential complications.

   Assessment and Plan
   75y/o M with a PMH of CAD s/p CABG with AVR in [**2164**] and
   thrombocytopenia transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] for management of S. aureus
   bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic CHF
   # Bacteremia - The patient was found to have 4/4 bottles growing
   Staphylococcus aureus. Concern for endovascular source of infection
   given high grade bacteremia. No clear portal of entry as the patient
   denies recent procedures/dental work, no focal symptoms. Given his
   presentation with community acquired bacteremia with symptoms of [**12-23**]
   day duration prior to presentation pt is at high risk for complicated
   bacteremia, including endocarditis. MSSA bacteremia speciation per new
   outside hospital records this morning.
   - Will switch to Nafcillin for better coverage of MSSA
   - TTE this AM
   - TEE today given bioprosthetic aortic valve
   - If evidence of vegetation or new/worsening valvular dysfunction,
   consider addition of gentamicin/rifamplin for S. aureus prosthetic
   valve endocarditis
   - Will obtain surveillance blood cultures
   - Appreciate ID recs
   .
   # Hypotension - Presentation of hypotension in setting of bacteremia
   could be consistent with sepsis, however the patient has a mixed
   picture given PCWP of 32 and CVP 14-24. Also consider worsening aortic
   valvular function in the setting of endocarditis. Currently, the
   patient appears volume overloaded with elevated JVP. Per reports
   pressor requirements have decreased since beginning diuresis.  Neo
   weaned off.  Dopamine weaned off overnight but restarted.  Patient
   pulled out PA catheter this AM.
   - Continue to taper dopamine
   - Continue lasix gtt
   - Treat bacteremia as above
   - TEE as above to evaluate EF/valvular dysfunction
   .
   # Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF - Pt currently with evidence of volume
   overload as above
   - continue lasix gtt
   - Plan for beta blocker and ACE-I once BP allows
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia - Per OSH reports the patient has a chronic
   thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology. Pt reports history of easy
   bleeding & bruising. DDx is broad and includes ITP, myelodysplastic
   syndrome, drug induced - ex. hydroxychloroquin, unclear when this was
   started, infection with HIV or HCV, nutritional deficiency
   (B12/Folate), EtOH toxicity however no clear history of this. DIC less
   concerning given long history of thrombocytopenia and fibrinogen
   normal. HIT also unlikely given documented long history of
   thrombocytopenia.  LFTs and LDH elevated.
   - check HIV
   - F/U B12/folate
   - Trend INR
   - Check peripheral smear
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation/Atrial Flutter - the pt reports a history of AF
   however no documented history of this, pt not on anticoagulation.
   Currently ECG shows A. flutter in the setting of pressors.  Currently
   Rate controlled.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Elevated CK/Troponin - No prior ECG for comparison, no clear
   ischemia. Trop bump most likely occurred in the setting of hypotension
   secondary to infection.  Likely demand in setting of hypotension. Not
   concerned for ACS.
   - Continue statin
   - Start BB and ACE-I as BP allows
   .
   # Encephalopathy - Most likely toxic/metabolic in the setting of
   infection. Per report OSH Head CT negative for acute process. Pt also
   had been treated with sedatives at OSH ativan/precedex .  Continues to
   be encephalopathic, though appears mildly improved.
   - Hold sedating medications
   - Treat infection
   - Consider repeat Head CT ; will likely need MRI in future when can
   tolerate to eval for septic emboli
   # Rheumatoid Arthritis
   - holding meds ; does not  likely need further stress dose steroids
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of CAD, s/p CABG with AVR, and thrombocytopenia, admitted to the ICU for management of S. aureus bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic CHF. He presented with bacteremia, sepsis, and endocarditis, and is currently receiving treatment for these conditions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening aortic valvular function: The patient's bioprosthetic aortic valve is thickened, and there is high-than-normal transvalvular gradient, which may worsen with time, leading to further complications.
2. Endocarditis: The patient has a high-grade bacteremia, which may lead to the development of endocarditis, especially in the setting of a bioprosthetic valve.
3. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and sepsis may lead to multi-organ dysfunction, including respiratory, cardiovascular, and renal failure.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's chronic thrombocytopenia may worsen with time, leading to increased bleeding risk and potential complications.
5. Encephalopathy: The patient's encephalopathy may be due to infection, metabolic, or toxic causes, and may worsen with time, leading to increased risk of complications.
6. Atrial fibrillation/flutter: The patient's atrial flutter may worsen with time, leading to increased risk of stroke and other complications.
7. Elevated CK/Troponin: The patient's elevated CK and Troponin levels may indicate cardiac damage, which may worsen with time, leading to increased risk of complications.
8. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may worsen with time, leading to decreased perfusion and increased risk of complications.
9. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status may worsen with time, leading to increased risk of complications, including respiratory failure.
10. Renal failure: The patient's renal function may worsen with time, leading to increased risk of complications, including acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.

Recommendations:

1. Continue treatment for bacteremia, sepsis, and endocarditis.
2. Monitor the patient's aortic valve function closely for signs of worsening valvular dysfunction.
3. Consider repeat TEE to evaluate EF/valvular dysfunction.
4. Continue lasix gtt to manage volume overload.
5. Taper dopamine and consider weaning off pressors.
6. Monitor the patient's thrombocytopenia and consider transfusions if necessary.
7. Consider repeat Head CT and MRI to evaluate for septic emboli.
8. Monitor the patient's encephalopathy and consider repeat Head CT if necessary.
9. Consider starting beta blocker and ACE-I once BP allows.
10. Monitor the patient's respiratory and renal function closely and consider interventions as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, I will summarize the patient's condition and potential medical complications that can arise.

Patient Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and a bioprosthetic aortic valve replacement (AVR) in 2014. He was admitted to the hospital with bacteremia caused by Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) and was found to have a small vegetation on his aortic valve. The patient has a mixed picture with signs of sepsis, including hypotension, tachycardia, and elevated lactate levels. He also has acute kidney injury, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Endocarditis: The patient's condition is complicated by prosthetic aortic valve endocarditis, which requires ongoing antibiotic therapy to prevent further valve damage and potential systemic complications.
2. Sepsis: The patient's mixed picture of sepsis, including hypotension, tachycardia, and elevated lactate levels, increases his risk of developing multi-organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS).
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's AKI may be pre-renal due to poor forward flow, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and potential for recovery.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may be caused by infection, sepsis, or underlying bone marrow disorder, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and potential for recovery.
5. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient's hyperbilirubinemia may be caused by cholecystitis, acalculous cholecystitis, or obstructing mass, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and potential for recovery.
6. Atrial Fibrillation/Atrial Flutter: The patient's atrial fibrillation/flutter may be caused by infection, sepsis, or underlying cardiac condition, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and potential for recovery.
7. Encephalopathy: The patient's encephalopathy may be caused by infection, sepsis, or underlying metabolic disorder, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and potential for recovery.
8. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's bacteremia and endocarditis increase his risk of developing cardiovascular complications, including valve dysfunction, heart failure, and myocardial infarction.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent further complications.

   75y/o M with a PMH of CAD s/p CABG with AVR in [**2164**] and
   thrombocytopenia transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] for management of S. aureus
   bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic CHF
   # Bacteremia - The patient was found to have 4/4 bottles growing
   Staphylococcus aureus. Concern for endovascular source of infection
   given high grade bacteremia. No clear portal of entry as the patient
   denies recent procedures/dental work, no focal symptoms. Given his
   presentation with community acquired bacteremia with symptoms of [**12-23**]
   day duration prior to presentation pt is at high risk for complicated
   bacteremia, including endocarditis. MSSA bacteremia speciation per new
   outside hospital records this morning.
   - Continue nafcillin given aortic vegetation
   - confer with ID concerning gent/rifampin dosing.
   - Will obtain surveillance blood cultures
   - Appreciate ID recs
   .
   # Hypotension - Presentation of hypotension in setting of bacteremia
   could be consistent with sepsis, however the patient has a mixed
   picture given PCWP of 32 and CVP 14-24. Also consider worsening aortic
   valvular function in the setting of endocarditis. Currently, the
   patient appears volume overloaded with elevated JVP. Per reports
   pressor requirements have decreased since beginning diuresis.  Neo
   weaned off.  Dopamine weaned off overnight but restarted.  Patient
   pulled out PA catheter this AM.
   - neo as needed.
   - will try to keep even as patient has possibly distributive shock
   picture from bacteremia.
   - Treat bacteremia as above
   # Acute Kidney injury
 may be pre-renal currently due to poor forward
   flow, although urine WBCs suggest potentially AIN.  No red cell casts
   that would be consistent with glomerulonephritis.
   -          trend creatinine
   -          appreciate renal recs.
   -          Follow up anca/[**Doctor First Name **]
   .
   # Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF - Pt currently with evidence of volume
   overload as above
   - lasix if patient has respiratory distress, however keep even for now.
   - Plan for beta blocker and ACE-I once BP allows
   .
   #Hyperbilirubinemia
 will acquire RUQ ultrasound to evaluate for
   cholecystitis, although acalculous cholecystitis possible in setting of
   critical illness.  Also look for obstructing mass.
   - fractionate bilis
   # Thrombocytopenia - Per OSH reports the patient has a chronic
   thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology. Pt reports history of easy
   bleeding & bruising. DDx is broad and includes ITP, myelodysplastic
   syndrome, drug induced - ex. hydroxychloroquin, unclear when this was
   started, infection with HIV or HCV, nutritional deficiency
   (B12/Folate), EtOH toxicity however no clear history of this. DIC less
   concerning given long history of thrombocytopenia and fibrinogen
   normal. HIT also unlikely given documented long history of
   thrombocytopenia.  LFTs and LDH elevated. Peripheral smear showed no
   schistocytes.
   - check HIV
   - F/U B12/folate
   - Trend INR
   - appreciate heme recs.
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation/Atrial Flutter - the pt reports a history of AF
   however no documented history of this, pt not on anticoagulation.
   Currently ECG shows A. flutter in the setting of pressors.  Currently
   Rate controlled.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Elevated CK/Troponin - No prior ECG for comparison, no clear
   ischemia. Trop bump most likely occurred in the setting of hypotension
   secondary to infection.  Likely demand in setting of hypotension. Not
   concerned for ACS.
   - Continue statin
   - Start BB and ACE-I as BP allows
   .
   # Encephalopathy - Most likely toxic/metabolic in the setting of
   infection. Per report OSH Head CT negative for acute process. Pt also
   had been treated with sedatives at OSH ativan/precedex .  Continues to
   be encephalopathic, though appears mildly improved.
   - Hold sedating medications
   - Treat infection
   - repeat Head CT ; will likely need MRI in future when can tolerate to
   eval for septic emboli
   # Rheumatoid Arthritis
   - holding meds ; does not  likely need further stress dose steroids
   ICU Care

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting and aortic valve replacement (AVR) in the past. He was admitted to the hospital with Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic congestive heart failure. The patient has a small vegetation on the aortic valve, which is consistent with endocarditis. He also has a mixed picture of sepsis, with a central venous pressure (CVP) of 14-24 mmHg and a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) of 32 mmHg.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 7.7 x 10^9/L, a hemoglobin level of 12.3 g/dL, and a platelet count of 43 x 10^9/L. His liver function tests (LFTs) are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 46 IU/L and an alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level of 55 IU/L. His creatinine level is 2.7 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level is 26 mg/dL.

The patient has been treated with nafcillin, phenylephrine, midazolam, and fentanyl. He has also received a dose of gentamicin and rifampin. The patient's blood cultures have grown Staphylococcus aureus, and he has been treated with antibiotics.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.2C, a heart rate of 93 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 88/47 mmHg, and a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation is 98%, and he is receiving oxygen via a nasal cannula.

Potential medical complications:

1. Endocarditis: The patient has a small vegetation on the aortic valve, which is consistent with endocarditis. This can lead to further complications, such as valve dysfunction, embolization, and sepsis.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a mixed picture of sepsis, with a CVP of 14-24 mmHg and a PCWP of 32 mmHg. This can lead to further complications, such as organ dysfunction, hypotension, and death.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is 2.7 mg/dL, which is consistent with acute kidney injury. This can lead to further complications, such as electrolyte imbalances, fluid overload, and death.
4. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient's bilirubin level is elevated, which can lead to further complications, such as jaundice, pruritus, and cholestasis.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's platelet count is 43 x 10^9/L, which is consistent with thrombocytopenia. This can lead to further complications, such as bleeding, petechiae, and purpura.
6. Atrial fibrillation/atrial flutter: The patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) shows atrial fibrillation/atrial flutter, which can lead to further complications, such as stroke, embolization, and heart failure.
7. Encephalopathy: The patient's mental status is altered, which can lead to further complications, such as confusion, disorientation, and seizures.

Overall, the patient is at high risk for further complications due to his underlying medical conditions and the severity of his infection. Close monitoring and treatment are necessary to prevent and manage these complications.

   concerning given long history of thrombocytopenia and fibrinogen
   normal. HIT also unlikely given documented long history of
   thrombocytopenia.  LFTs and LDH elevated. Peripheral smear showed no
   schistocytes.
   - check HIV
   - F/U B12/folate
   - Trend INR
   - heme consult
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation/Atrial Flutter - the pt reports a history of AF
   however no documented history of this, pt not on anticoagulation.
   Currently ECG shows A. flutter in the setting of pressors.  Currently
   Rate controlled.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   .
   # Elevated CK/Troponin - No prior ECG for comparison, no clear
   ischemia. Trop bump most likely occurred in the setting of hypotension
   secondary to infection.  Likely demand in setting of hypotension. Not
   concerned for ACS.
   - Continue statin
   - Start BB and ACE-I as BP allows
   .
   # Encephalopathy - Most likely toxic/metabolic in the setting of
   infection. Per report OSH Head CT negative for acute process. Pt also
   had been treated with sedatives at OSH ativan/precedex .  Continues to
   be encephalopathic, though appears mildly improved.
   - Hold sedating medications
   - Treat infection
   - repeat Head CT ; will likely need MRI in future when can tolerate to
   eval for septic emboli
   # Rheumatoid Arthritis
   - holding meds ; does not  likely need further stress dose steroids
   ICU Care

He was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic congestive heart failure.

The patient has been experiencing hypotension, which could be attributed to sepsis or worsening aortic valvular function due to endocarditis. He has also been experiencing thrombocytopenia, which is of unclear etiology. The patient has a history of easy bleeding and bruising, and the differential diagnosis includes idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura, myelodysplastic syndrome, drug-induced thrombocytopenia, infection with HIV or HCV, nutritional deficiency, and ethanol toxicity.

The patient has been treated with antibiotics, diuresis, and pressors, and his condition has been monitored closely. He has also been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation and elevated CK and troponin levels, which are likely due to hypotension and demand ischemia.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and endocarditis can lead to sepsis, which can cause organ failure and death.
2. Endocarditis: The patient's aortic valve replacement and bacteremia can lead to endocarditis, which can cause valvular dysfunction and embolization.
3. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia can lead to bleeding complications, including intracranial hemorrhage.
4. Cardiac failure: The patient's acute on chronic systolic congestive heart failure can lead to cardiac failure, which can cause pulmonary edema and death.
5. Encephalopathy: The patient's infection and encephalopathy can lead to confusion, disorientation, and seizures.
6. Renal failure: The patient's bacteremia and sepsis can lead to acute kidney injury, which can cause renal failure.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient's bacteremia and sepsis can lead to respiratory failure, which can cause hypoxia and death.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, laboratory results, and imaging studies closely to detect any potential complications early.

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and a recent diagnosis of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia. He was admitted to the hospital with symptoms of acute on chronic systolic heart failure, and has been treated with nafcillin and diuresis. The patient has developed hypotension, acute kidney injury, and hyperbilirubinemia, and is currently being treated with pressors and diuretics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and hypotension increase the risk of sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
2. Endocarditis: The patient's bacteremia and aortic valve vegetation increase the risk of endocarditis, which can lead to valve destruction and embolic complications.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's AKI may be pre-renal due to poor forward flow, but urine WBCs suggest potentially AIN. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of AKI.
4. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient's hyperbilirubinemia may be due to cholecystitis or an obstructing mass. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of hyperbilirubinemia.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may be due to ITP, myelodysplastic syndrome, or infection with HIV or HCV. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of thrombocytopenia.
6. Atrial Fibrillation/Atrial Flutter: The patient's atrial fibrillation/flutter may be due to infection or electrolyte imbalance. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of atrial fibrillation/flutter.
7. Encephalopathy: The patient's encephalopathy may be due to toxic/metabolic causes or septic emboli. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of encephalopathy.
8. Rheumatoid Arthritis: The patient's rheumatoid arthritis may be exacerbating his symptoms. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause of rheumatoid arthritis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to treat the patient's bacteremia with nafcillin and diuresis.
2. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and cardiac function closely.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's renal function and consider further evaluation for AKI.
4. Consider further evaluation for hyperbilirubinemia, including RUQ ultrasound and liver function tests.
5. Consider further evaluation for thrombocytopenia, including HIV testing and B12/folate levels.
6. Monitor the patient's atrial fibrillation/flutter and consider further evaluation for underlying causes.
7. Monitor the patient's encephalopathy and consider further evaluation for septic emboli.
8. Consider further evaluation for rheumatoid arthritis, including medication management and physical therapy.

   Differential-Neuts:82.5 %, Band:0.0 %, Lymph:6.6 %, Mono:10.5 %,
   Eos:0.4 %, Fibrinogen:314 mg/dL, Lactic Acid:1.8 mmol/L, Albumin:2.2
   g/dL, LDH:405 IU/L, Ca++:6.8 mg/dL, Mg++:2.9 mg/dL, PO4:4.1 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   75y/o M with a PMH of CAD s/p CABG with AVR in [**2164**] and
   thrombocytopenia transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] for management of S. aureus
   bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic CHF
   # Bacteremia/ Endocarditis - The patient was found to have 4/4 bottles
   growing Staphylococcus aureus. Concern for endovascular source of
   infection given high grade bacteremia. No clear portal of entry as the
   patient denies recent procedures/dental work, no focal symptoms. Given
   his presentation with community acquired bacteremia with symptoms of
   [**12-23**] day duration prior to presentation pt is at high risk for
   complicated bacteremia, including endocarditis. MSSA bacteremia
   speciation.  + vegetation on bioprosthetic aortic valve.
   - On nafcillin given aortic vegetation but may need to switch to Vanc
   in setting of possible AIN
   - has not started Gent due to worsening renal function
   - continue surveillance blood cultures
   - Appreciate ID recs
   .
   # Hypotension -  appears to be in Distributive shock.  Neo weaned off
   with fluid challenge last night but restarted early this AM.  AM
   cortisol yesterday normal.
   - will try to keep even as patient has possibly distributive shock
   picture from bacteremia.  Holding diuresis
   - Treat bacteremia as above
   - will fluid challenge very slowly and gently today
   - consider Swan tomorrow to help w fluid management if not improving
   - continue phenylephrine and attempting to wean
   # Acute Kidney injury
 Multifactorial, may be pre-renal currently due
   to poor forward flow, in addition to AIN as suggested by urine WBCs.
   Possibly also contribution of immune-mediated complexes.
   - may need to switch Nafcillin to Vancomycin in setting of AIN
   -          trend creatinine
   -          appreciate renal recs.
   -          Follow up anca/[**Doctor First Name **]
   .
   # Rash-  appears to be petechiae, increasing on back, unknown
   etiology.  Consider vasculitis vs chronic ITP
   - Rheumatology consult to consider restarting steroids
   .
   # Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF - Pt currently with evidence of volume
   overload as above
   - lasix if patient has respiratory distress, however keep even for now
   or mildly positive with fluid challenges.
   - Plan for beta blocker and ACE-I once BP allows
   #Hyperbilirubinemia
 RUQ ultrasound did not show evidence of septic
   emboli. Fractionated Bili shows increased Direct.  Stable from
   yesterday.
   - continue to monitor
   # Thrombocytopenia - Per OSH reports the patient has a chronic
   thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology. Pt reports history of easy
   bleeding & bruising. DDx is broad and includes ITP, myelodysplastic
   syndrome, drug induced - ex. hydroxychloroquin, unclear when this was
   started, infection with HIV or HCV, nutritional deficiency
   (B12/Folate), EtOH toxicity however no clear history of this. DIC less
   concerning given long history of thrombocytopenia and fibrinogen
   normal. HIT also unlikely given documented long history of
   thrombocytopenia.  LFTs and LDH elevated. Peripheral smear showed no
   schistocytes.
   - appreciate heme recs.
   # Atrial Fibrillation/Atrial Flutter - the pt reports a history of AF
   however no documented history of this, pt not on anticoagulation.
   Currently ECG shows A. flutter in the setting of pressors.  Currently
   Rate controlled.
   -          Monitor on telemetry
   -          ..
   # Encephalopathy - Most likely toxic/metabolic in the setting of
   infection. Per report OSH Head CT negative for acute process. Pt also
   had been treated with sedatives at OSH ativan/precedex .  Continues to
   be encephalopathic, though appears mildly improved.  Getting olanzapine
   here for agitation
   - Hold sedating medications
   - Treat infection
   - MRI in future when can tolerate to eval for septic emboli
   # Rheumatoid Arthritis
   -          holding meds
   -          Rheum consult
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   20 Gauge - [**2168-1-8**] 10:30 PM
   PICC Line - [**2168-1-9**] 11:00 AM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: Boots
   Stress ulcer:
   VAP:
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:CCU

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and aortic valve replacement (AVR) who was admitted to the hospital with Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus) bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic heart failure.

The patient's current condition is complicated by:

1. Distributive shock, possibly due to bacteremia, requiring fluid challenge and vasopressor support.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI), multifactorial in origin, with possible contributions from pre-renal factors, AIN, and immune-mediated complexes.
3. Thrombocytopenia, chronic in nature, with a broad differential diagnosis including ITP, myelodysplastic syndrome, drug-induced thrombocytopenia, and infection.
4. Hyperbilirubinemia, with increased direct bilirubin, and a possible diagnosis of Gilbert's syndrome.
5. Atrial fibrillation (AF), currently rate-controlled, with no documented history of anticoagulation.
6. Encephalopathy, likely toxic/metabolic in origin, with a history of sedative use and ongoing infection.
7. Rash, possibly vasculitis or chronic ITP, with a pending rheumatology consult.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Endocarditis, given the presence of aortic vegetation and high-grade bacteremia.
2. Septic shock, if the patient's distributive shock worsens or is not adequately managed.
3. Chronic kidney disease, if the patient's AKI progresses or is not reversible.
4. Gastrointestinal bleeding, if the patient's thrombocytopenia worsens or is not adequately managed.
5. Respiratory failure, if the patient's acute on chronic systolic heart failure worsens or is not adequately managed.
6. Neurological sequelae, if the patient's encephalopathy worsens or is not adequately managed.
7. Infection-related complications, such as sepsis or septic shock, if the patient's bacteremia is not adequately managed.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continued antibiotic therapy for S. aureus bacteremia.
2. Close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, fluid status, and renal function.
3. Serial creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels to monitor for AKI.
4. Regular platelet counts to monitor for thrombocytopenia.
5. Rheumatology consult for evaluation and management of the patient's rash.
6. Ongoing management of the patient's atrial fibrillation, including rate control and possible anticoagulation.
7. Further evaluation and management of the patient's encephalopathy, including possible MRI imaging to evaluate for septic emboli.

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, post-myocardial infarction, and aortic valve replacement. He was transferred to the ICU for management of Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic congestive heart failure. He has a high-grade bacteremia, and a vegetation was found on his bioprosthetic aortic valve. He is at risk for complicated bacteremia, including endocarditis. He is also experiencing hypotension, acute kidney injury, and thrombocytopenia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Endocarditis: The patient's bacteremia and vegetation on the bioprosthetic aortic valve increase his risk of developing endocarditis.
2. Renal Failure: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen, leading to further compromise of his kidney function.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may persist or worsen, leading to inadequate perfusion of vital organs.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia may worsen, increasing his risk of bleeding.
5. Encephalopathy: The patient's encephalopathy may persist or worsen, leading to further cognitive impairment and increased risk of complications.
6. Atrial Fibrillation/Atrial Flutter: The patient's atrial fibrillation/flutter may persist or worsen, leading to further cardiac complications.
7. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient's hyperbilirubinemia may worsen, leading to further liver dysfunction.
8. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): The patient's respiratory compromise may worsen, leading to ARDS.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and antifungals as prescribed.
2. Monitor the patient's blood cultures and adjust treatment accordingly.
3. Continue to manage the patient's hypotension with fluid challenges and vasopressors as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's renal function and adjust treatment accordingly.
5. Continue to manage the patient's thrombocytopenia with platelet transfusions as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's encephalopathy and adjust treatment accordingly.
7. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation/flutter with rate control medications as needed.
8. Monitor the patient's hyperbilirubinemia and adjust treatment accordingly.
9. Consider performing a Swan-Ganz catheterization to help guide fluid management.
10. Consider performing an MRI to evaluate for septic emboli.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

   75y/o M with a PMH of CAD s/p CABG with AVR in [**2164**] and
   thrombocytopenia transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] for management of MSSA bacteremia
   and acute on chronic systolic CHF c/b hypotension
   # Bacteremia/ Endocarditis - The patient was found to have 4/4 bottles
   growing Staphylococcus aureus at OSH. Concern for endovascular source
   of infection given high grade bacteremia. No clear portal of entry as
   the patient denies recent procedures/dental work, no focal symptoms.
   Given his presentation with community acquired bacteremia with symptoms
   of [**12-23**] day duration prior to presentation pt is at high risk for
   complicated bacteremia, including endocarditis. MSSA bacteremia
   speciation.  + vegetation on bioprosthetic aortic valve as witness on
   TEE.
   - On nafcillin given aortic vegetation (consider switching to vanc for
   AIN)
   - hold on gent due to renal function, hold on rifampin
   - continue surveillance blood cultures
   - Appreciate ID recs
   - consider further imaging to eval for AI - ? repeat TEE if worried (no
   new murmur, pulse pressure widening, EKG QRS prolongation)
   - appreciate CSurg recs
   # Hypotension -  has a mixed picture. Seems to be some component of
   distributive and cardiac shock. Phenylephrine was weaned off after
   successful fluid challenege. However, overnight patient became
   hypotensive requiring phenylephrine. Appears fluid overloaded on exam.
   - consider PA catheter for further hemodynamic monitoring
   - continue to treat endocarditis as above
   - wean pressor as tolerated
   - TTE
   # Acute kidney injury - less likely pre-renal. Likely AIN but may have
   immune-mediated complexes as well.
   - appreciate renal recs
   - urine lytes
   - trend BUN/Cr
   - f/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **], ANCA
   # Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF - Pt currently with evidence of volume
   overload as above. Required lasix last night for likely pulmonary
   edema.
   - consider PA catheter
   - lasix prn
   - plan for beta blocker, acei once bp allows
   # Rash-  appears to be petechiae, increasing on back, unknown
   etiology.  Consider vasculitis vs chronic ITP. Derm thinks likely heat
   rash. No need to biopsy.
   - keep back dry
   - cream for back
   #Hyperbilirubinemia
 RUQ ultrasound did not show evidence of septic
   emboli. Fractionated Bili shows increased Direct.  Stable from
   yesterday.
   - continue to monitor
   # Thrombocytopenia - Per OSH reports the patient has a chronic
   thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology. Pt reports history of easy
   bleeding & bruising. DDx is broad and includes ITP, myelodysplastic
   syndrome, drug induced - ex. hydroxychloroquin, unclear when this was
   started, infection with HIV or HCV, nutritional deficiency
   (B12/Folate), EtOH toxicity however no clear history of this. DIC less
   concerning given long history of thrombocytopenia and fibrinogen
   normal. HIT also unlikely given documented long history of
   thrombocytopenia.  LFTs and LDH elevated. Peripheral smear showed no
   schistocytes.
   - appreciate heme recs
   # Atrial Fibrillation/Atrial Flutter - the pt reports a history of AF
   however no documented history of this, pt not on anticoagulation.
   Currently ECG shows A. flutter in the setting of pressors.  Currently
   Rate controlled.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - hold anticoagulation due to thrombocytopenia
   # Encephalopathy - Most likely toxic/metabolic in the setting of
   infection. Per report OSH Head CT negative for acute process. Pt also
   had been treated with sedatives at OSH ativan/precedex .  Continues to
   be encephalopathic, though appears mildly improved.  Getting olanzapine
   here for agitation
   - Hold sedating medications
   - Treat infection
   - MRI in future when can tolerate to eval for septic emboli
   # other
   - ionized calcium

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with a past medical history of CAD, s/p CABG with AVR, and thrombocytopenia. He was transferred to the ICU for management of MSSA bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic CHF. The patient has a mixed picture of hypotension, with a component of distributive and cardiac shock. He has acute kidney injury, likely due to AIN, and is at high risk for complicated bacteremia, including endocarditis. He also has a rash, likely heat rash, and thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology.

Potential medical complications:

1. Endocarditis: The patient has a high-grade bacteremia and a vegetation on his bioprosthetic aortic valve, making endocarditis a concern.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's kidney function is compromised, and he requires close monitoring and management.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a high risk of developing sepsis due to his bacteremia and underlying medical conditions.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac function is compromised, and he may be at risk for cardiac complications such as cardiac arrest or arrhythmias.
5. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is compromised, and he may be at risk for respiratory failure.
6. Neurological complications: The patient has encephalopathy and may be at risk for neurological complications such as seizures or stroke.
7. Bleeding complications: The patient's thrombocytopenia increases his risk of bleeding complications.
8. Infection: The patient has a high risk of developing further infections due to his immunocompromised state.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to manage the patient's bacteremia and endocarditis with antibiotics and close monitoring.
2. Monitor the patient's kidney function and adjust his fluid management accordingly.
3. Consider further imaging studies to evaluate for cardiac and respiratory complications.
4. Monitor the patient's neurological status and consider further evaluation with imaging studies if necessary.
5. Continue to manage the patient's bleeding risk with close monitoring and transfusions as necessary.
6. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's rash.
7. Continue to monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust his antihypertensive medications as necessary.
8. Consider further evaluation and management of the patient's hyperbilirubinemia.

   Assessment and Plan
   75y/o M with a PMH of CAD s/p CABG with AVR in [**2164**] and
   thrombocytopenia transferred to [**Hospital1 5**] for management of MSSA bacteremia
   and acute on chronic systolic CHF c/b hypotension
   # Bacteremia/ Endocarditis - The patient was found to have 4/4 bottles
   growing Staphylococcus aureus at OSH. Concern for endovascular source
   of infection given high grade bacteremia. No clear portal of entry as
   the patient denies recent procedures/dental work, no focal symptoms.
   Given his presentation with community acquired bacteremia with symptoms
   of [**12-23**] day duration prior to presentation pt is at high risk for
   complicated bacteremia, including endocarditis. MSSA bacteremia
   speciation.  + vegetation on bioprosthetic aortic valve as witness on
   TEE.
   - On nafcillin given aortic vegetation (consider switching to vanc for
   AIN)
   - hold on gent due to renal function, hold on rifampin
   - continue surveillance blood cultures
   - Appreciate ID recs
   - consider further imaging to eval for AI - ? repeat TEE if worried (no
   new murmur, pulse pressure widening, EKG QRS prolongation)
   - appreciate CSurg recs
   # Hypotension -  has a mixed picture. Seems to be some component of
   distributive and cardiac shock. Phenylephrine was weaned off after
   successful fluid challenege. However, overnight patient became
   hypotensive requiring phenylephrine. Appears fluid overloaded on exam.
   - consider PA catheter for further hemodynamic monitoring
   - continue to treat endocarditis as above
   - wean pressor as tolerated
   - TTE
   # Acute kidney injury - less likely pre-renal. Likely AIN but may have
   immune-mediated complexes as well.
   - appreciate renal recs
   - urine lytes
   - trend BUN/Cr
   - f/[**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) **], ANCA
   # Acute on Chronic Systolic CHF - Pt currently with evidence of volume
   overload as above. Required lasix last night for likely pulmonary
   edema.
   - consider PA catheter
   - lasix prn
   - plan for beta blocker, acei once bp allows
   # Rash-  appears to be petechiae, increasing on back, unknown
   etiology.  Consider vasculitis vs chronic ITP. Derm thinks likely heat
   rash. No need to biopsy.
   - keep back dry
   - cream for back
   #Hyperbilirubinemia
 RUQ ultrasound did not show evidence of septic
   emboli. Fractionated Bili shows increased Direct.  Stable from
   yesterday.
   - continue to monitor
   # Thrombocytopenia - Per OSH reports the patient has a chronic
   thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology. Pt reports history of easy
   bleeding & bruising. DDx is broad and includes ITP, myelodysplastic
   syndrome, drug induced - ex. hydroxychloroquin, unclear when this was
   started, infection with HIV or HCV, nutritional deficiency
   (B12/Folate), EtOH toxicity however no clear history of this. DIC less
   concerning given long history of thrombocytopenia and fibrinogen
   normal. HIT also unlikely given documented long history of
   thrombocytopenia.  LFTs and LDH elevated. Peripheral smear showed no
   schistocytes.
   - appreciate heme recs
   # Atrial Fibrillation/Atrial Flutter - the pt reports a history of AF
   however no documented history of this, pt not on anticoagulation.
   Currently ECG shows A. flutter in the setting of pressors.  Currently
   Rate controlled.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - hold anticoagulation due to thrombocytopenia
   # Encephalopathy - Most likely toxic/metabolic in the setting of
   infection. Per report OSH Head CT negative for acute process. Pt also
   had been treated with sedatives at OSH ativan/precedex .  Continues to
   be encephalopathic, though appears mildly improved.  Getting olanzapine
   here for agitation
   - Hold sedating medications
   - Treat infection
   - MRI in future when can tolerate to eval for septic emboli
   # other
   - ionized calcium
   ICU Care

   Glycemic Control:

Summary:

The patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and thrombocytopenia who was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for management of methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF). The patient has a mixed picture of hypotension, with components of distributive and cardiac shock, and is receiving phenylephrine to support his blood pressure. He has a history of easy bleeding and bruising, and his platelet count is low. The patient has also developed a rash, which is thought to be petechiae, and has evidence of acute kidney injury (AKI).

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Endocarditis: The patient has a high-grade bacteremia and a vegetation on his bioprosthetic aortic valve, which increases the risk of endocarditis.
2. Sepsis: The patient has a severe infection, which can lead to sepsis, a life-threatening condition.
3. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient has AKI, which can progress to chronic kidney disease if not treated promptly and effectively.
4. Hypotension: The patient has hypotension, which can lead to organ failure if not treated promptly and effectively.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has thrombocytopenia, which can increase the risk of bleeding and bruising.
6. Encephalopathy: The patient has encephalopathy, which can be caused by infection, metabolic disorders, or toxic substances.
7. Cardiac Arrest: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation and is at risk of cardiac arrest if not treated promptly and effectively.
8. Pulmonary Edema: The patient has evidence of pulmonary edema, which can lead to respiratory failure if not treated promptly and effectively.
9. Infection: The patient has a severe infection, which can lead to sepsis, organ failure, and death if not treated promptly and effectively.

Recommendations:

1. Continue antibiotics and antifungal therapy to treat the patient's MSSA bacteremia and possible endocarditis.
2. Monitor the patient's blood pressure and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent hypotension.
3. Continue to treat the patient's AKI with fluids, diuretics, and renal replacement therapy as necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's platelet count and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent bleeding and bruising.
5. Monitor the patient's encephalopathy and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent further decline.
6. Consider placement of a pulmonary artery catheter to monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust therapy as necessary.
7. Monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent cardiac arrest.
8. Consider placement of a central venous catheter to monitor the patient's central venous pressure and adjust therapy as necessary.
9. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent respiratory failure.

   rash. No need to biopsy.
   - keep back dry
   - cream for back
   #Hyperbilirubinemia
 RUQ ultrasound did not show evidence of septic
   emboli. Fractionated Bili shows increased Direct.  Stable from
   yesterday.
   - continue to monitor
   # Thrombocytopenia - Per OSH reports the patient has a chronic
   thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology. Pt reports history of easy
   bleeding & bruising. DDx is broad and includes ITP, myelodysplastic
   syndrome, drug induced - ex. hydroxychloroquin, unclear when this was
   started, infection with HIV or HCV, nutritional deficiency
   (B12/Folate), EtOH toxicity however no clear history of this. DIC less
   concerning given long history of thrombocytopenia and fibrinogen
   normal. HIT also unlikely given documented long history of
   thrombocytopenia.  LFTs and LDH elevated. Peripheral smear showed no
   schistocytes.
   - appreciate heme recs
   # Atrial Fibrillation/Atrial Flutter - the pt reports a history of AF
   however no documented history of this, pt not on anticoagulation.
   Currently ECG shows A. flutter in the setting of pressors.  Currently
   Rate controlled.
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - hold anticoagulation due to thrombocytopenia
   # Encephalopathy - Most likely toxic/metabolic in the setting of
   infection. Per report OSH Head CT negative for acute process. Pt also
   had been treated with sedatives at OSH ativan/precedex .  Continues to
   be encephalopathic, though appears mildly improved.  Getting olanzapine
   here for agitation
   - Hold sedating medications
   - Treat infection
   - MRI in future when can tolerate to eval for septic emboli

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and thrombocytopenia who was transferred to the hospital for management of methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF).

The patient has a mixed picture of hypotension, with a component of distributive and cardiac shock. He was initially treated with phenylephrine, which was weaned off after a successful fluid challenge. However, he became hypotensive again overnight, requiring the reintroduction of phenylephrine.

The patient also has acute kidney injury (AKI), which is likely due to allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN) rather than pre-renal causes. He has a history of thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology and is at risk for complications such as endocarditis.

The patient has a rash on his back, which is thought to be likely heat rash, but the etiology is unknown. He also has hyperbilirubinemia, which is being monitored.

The patient has atrial fibrillation/flutter, which is being rate-controlled. He is not on anticoagulation due to his thrombocytopenia.

The patient is encephalopathic, likely due to toxic/metabolic causes, and is being treated with olanzapine for agitation.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Endocarditis: Given the patient's history of bacteremia and the presence of a bioprosthetic aortic valve, there is a risk of endocarditis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and hyperbilirubinemia increase his risk of developing sepsis.
3. AKI: The patient's AKI is likely to progress if not managed appropriately.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's thrombocytopenia increases his risk of bleeding complications.
5. Cardiac complications: The patient's CHF and atrial fibrillation/flutter increase his risk of cardiac complications such as heart failure, arrhythmias, and cardiogenic shock.
6. Encephalopathy: The patient's encephalopathy can progress to more severe forms of brain dysfunction, such as sepsis-induced encephalopathy or cerebral edema.
7. Hyperbilirubinemia: The patient's hyperbilirubinemia can lead to kernicterus, a condition characterized by brain damage and seizures.

To address these potential complications, the patient should be closely monitored for signs of sepsis, AKI, and cardiac complications. His thrombocytopenia should be managed with platelet transfusions and anticoagulation therapy. His hyperbilirubinemia should be monitored, and his encephalopathy should be treated with sedatives and anticonvulsants as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 75-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) post-coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) with aortic valve replacement (AVR) and thrombocytopenia. He was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for management of methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus (MSSA) bacteremia and acute on chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF).

The patient's current condition is characterized by:

1. Hypotension: The patient has a mixed picture of distributive and cardiac shock, with phenylephrine being weaned off after successful fluid challenge, but requiring reintroduction overnight.
2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient has evidence of AKI, likely due to acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) or immune-mediated complexes.
3. Acute on chronic systolic CHF: The patient has evidence of volume overload, requiring lasix last night for likely pulmonary edema.
4. Rash: The patient has a petechial rash on his back, of unknown etiology, with a differential diagnosis including vasculitis, chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), and heat rash.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a chronic thrombocytopenia of unclear etiology, with a broad differential diagnosis including ITP, myelodysplastic syndrome, drug-induced thrombocytopenia, infection with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) or hepatitis C virus (HCV), nutritional deficiency, and ethanol toxicity.
6. Atrial fibrillation/atrial flutter: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, but no documented history, and is currently in atrial flutter, with a rate-controlled rhythm.
7. Encephalopathy: The patient has a history of encephalopathy, likely due to toxic or metabolic causes in the setting of infection.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Endocarditis: The patient has a high-grade bacteremia, and a vegetation on his bioprosthetic aortic valve, which may lead to endocarditis.
2. Sepsis: The patient's bacteremia and encephalopathy increase his risk of developing sepsis.
3. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient's pulmonary edema and hypotension increase his risk of developing ARDS.
4. Renal failure: The patient's AKI and underlying chronic kidney disease increase his risk of developing renal failure.
5. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter increase his risk of developing other cardiac arrhythmias.
6. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's thrombocytopenia and history of easy bleeding increase his risk of developing gastrointestinal bleeding.

The patient's current plan includes:

1. Continuation of antibiotics for MSSA bacteremia and endocarditis.
2. Fluid management to prevent volume overload and hypotension.
3. Monitoring of renal function and consideration of further imaging to evaluate for AKI.
4. Treatment of atrial fibrillation/atrial flutter with rate control and consideration of anticoagulation once thrombocytopenia improves.
5. Monitoring of encephalopathy and consideration of further imaging to evaluate for septic emboli.
6. Management of rash and consideration of further evaluation to determine etiology.
7. Monitoring of blood counts and consideration of further evaluation to determine etiology of thrombocytopenia.
